content.description: Stem out of the wide crack to the less wide off with and the top.
content.location: Grape Juice Wall: Ten feet left of Pressed

content.description: Start up the either the first or second opening, your choice, and stay right climbing the line of least resistance up the right side of the slab. A horizontal crack offers a piece of gear before the last stretch.
content.location:
The Nursery  

  The first route when approaching along the climbers path from the Grape Juice Wall.

content.description: Scramble up the beginning of Pigs then move left to a large ledge below two cleaned lines. This is the left hand one.
content.location:
The Nursery  

  Twenty five feet left of Pigs

content.description: Scramble up the beginning of Pigs then move left to a large ledge below two cleaned lines. This is the right hand one.
content.location:
The Nursery  

  Fifteen feet left of "Pigs"

content.description:
"The Best for Juice"  

  Excellent technical climbing on unparalleled granite make this highball one of my personal favorites. 

  Find some holds of some value pull of the ground, then delicate footwork up then right to a stance on the ramp gains a final good hold for the top out. Exciting!
content.protection: The ground here is soft and the crux is relativity low.
content.location: Grape Juice Wall: The first route you will see when approaching from the hiking trail. Steuben starts in the center of the wall just left of the top out.

content.description: A fun tight corner with the crux at the top, very good.
content.location: Grape Juice Wall: Five feet right of Grape Juice

content.description: A great little crack although maybe a bit sharp. This route is named for the landing...
content.location: Grape juice Wall: Furthest route to the right

content.description:
A good fun slab, if you're into that sort of thing.  

  Make thin balance moves up and left aiming for a nice solution pocket.
content.protection: Long paints and shirt are nice for pro, A TR can be set up with gear.
content.location: Grape Juice Wall: Start three feet left of Hippies...and just right of a small bush.

content.description: A couple of moves off the ground find you awkwardly in a horizontal crack that runs in both directions. Climb left about 60 feet until the crack ends on a ledge about eight feet off the ground.
content.protection: I used a variety of gear, it takes it and it's always polite to protect the second as well.
content.location:
The Nursery 

  About 55 feet left, up hill from "The Golden Road" starts next to a small hemlock on featured rock.
Grape Juice Wall: Five feet left of the short wide chimney splitting the wall.

content.description:
Very cool route with distinctive memorable features interesting movement and even a stopper crux, I would characterise as being quite thin. 

   Start about ten feet left of a very cool vertical basin feature. Climb up and make a mantelish  move up into two large pockets, do a little jig looking for the next move, then crimp and edge on up to the slab above where the climbing eases. Follow a groove to the top and a rap station.
content.protection:
TR for now there are two possible placements it could go but would be spicy!  

  Located in the Nursery   About twenty feet left of "The Golden Road"

content.description: A couple of cool moves around the flake, then join Naturally Sweetened
content.location: Grape Juice Wall: Ten feet Right of The Stem, and ten feet left of Big Grapes

content.description: Climb up the corner crack angeling left to the top.
Climb the boulder choked ramp to the top, fun.
content.protection: A couple of good spliffs should to do ya.
content.location: Grape Juice Wall: Five feet left of Tree Hugger.

content.description: Go to summit of Welch Mt. On the northeast side is long black slab with a ceiling slightly below the summit also known as the big east slab. Get to the ceiling by a scary traverse ledge above the 400ft+ mostly black slab, (driving south this slab is the first slab seen).    This traverse ledge goes to three distinct vertical hand cracks. Climb the cracks. If you fall off, fall forever. The crack furthest right or north is the hardest. I free soloed them and all 5.7+ soloed can mean 5.9. Perfect for locking into the cracks with hand jams. That's why I did all three instead of one.   The big black slab has seepage most of the year. I don't know the way to its base. Its in a hard to get to place.
content.protection: The cracks would take medium to large cams. I used no pro and had no rope.
content.location: Summit Welch Mt. and then down climb around to the ceiling above the northeast black slab. This wide low angle slab is the first slab seen going south from Waterville Valley. The cracks can be seen also.

content.description:
After discovering this crag Nick led this route, his second trad lead!  

  A short corner to good crack climbing.
content.location: Grape Juice Wall: Ten feet right of Concord Crack.

content.description:
The start is bouldery and may be a tad crumbly but overall this is a clean natural line, Very Good. 

  Face climb past a tree and up onto a low angle slab. From here follow a corner up to the tree line then step left onto the face and out a low angel arete to a rap station atop.
content.location:
The Nursery  

  About 20 feet right of "Pocket Dancing'

content.description: A very nice off width, real fun
content.protection: I think a number 5 would fit.
content.location: Grape Juice Wall: Just right of the wide chimney splitting the wall.

content.description:
With its many small crags and superb views you may want to stop and climb something along the hike. If so bring a small rack and a rope to see what you can find. The best crags are found near the summit.The routes are short but of the same high quality as neighbouring Dickey Ledge. The big east facing slab that is seen from Rt. 49 is more suitable for skiing than climbing.  

  As of right now there are four small crags with established routes on them listed in descending elevation, west to east and left to right if looking up the Welch Mtn. trail they are, The Summit Cliff, The Nursery, Grape Juice Wall, and The Hikers Wall. More info soon.
